title: 112_s3196
content: The Act titled "National Women's High-Growth Business Bipartisan Task Force Act of 2012" establishes the National Women's High-Growth Business Bipartisan Task Force, defining key terms such as "Administration" and "Task Force." The National Women's High-Growth Business Bipartisan Task Force is established to provide advice and recommendations to the Administrator, Assistant Administrator, Congress, the President, and other federal departments. It consists of 15 members, including 8 individuals who own small business concerns controlled by women. The National Women's High-Growth Business Bipartisan Task Force consists of 15 members, including individuals with expertise in women's business, entrepreneurship, and new business development. 2 members are appointed by the Chairperson of the Committee on Small Business and Entrepreneurship of the Senate. The National Women's High-Growth Business Bipartisan Task Force includes 15 members with expertise in women's business and entrepreneurship. Members are appointed by the Senate and House Committees on Small Business. Additional members are appointed by the Administrator. The National Women's High-Growth Business Bipartisan Task Force, consisting of 15 members, must appoint initial members within 90 days of the Act's enactment. Geographic diversity is considered in appointments to ensure representation from rural areas. No more than 8 members can be from the same political party. The Task Force elects a chairperson from its members. The Task Force, consisting of 15 members, elects a Chairperson. Vacancies are filled at the first meeting after they occur. Members serve a 3-year term, with initial appointees serving for 4 years. The Task Force consists of 15 members, with 5 appointed for a 5-year term. Vacancies are filled promptly. (5) Vacancies on the Task Force must be filled within 30 days in the same manner as the original appointment, with the new member serving the unexpired term. (6) Task Force members are generally prohibited from federal employment, but exceptions exist for those who accept such positions after their Task Force appointment. The Task Force members serve without compensation and are reimbursed for travel expenses. Their duties include reviewing plans affecting women-owned small businesses' access to capital and markets. The Task Force members review and promote initiatives to support women-owned small businesses, advise on joint efforts for their development, and coordinate federal programs for their formation and growth. The Task Force focuses on supporting women-owned small businesses, examining their link to intellectual property, and may hold hearings and establish task groups to carry out its duties. The Task Force may establish temporary task groups, request information from federal agencies, use the United States mails, and accept gifts. Meetings shall occur at least 3 times a year, at the Chairperson's call, or upon request of the Administrator. The Task Force, upon request from specific entities, allows participation of federal agency representatives in meetings as resources without voting rights. The Task Force meetings are typically held at the Administration's headquarters, but can be held elsewhere if agreed upon by the majority of members in advance. The Administrator is responsible for providing meeting facilities and necessary administrative support. The Task Force must submit reports to the President and the Senate Committee on Small Business and Entrepreneurship within 30 days after the end of each fiscal year. The Task Force must submit a report to the Senate Committee on Small Business containing a detailed description of its activities, findings, recommendations, and suggestions for promoting intellectual property rights for small businesses owned by women. The Task Force will submit a report to promote small businesses owned by women, including legislative actions and reports with Administrator views and meeting minutes. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy will conduct studies regularly. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration, in consultation with the Task Force, conducts biannual studies on issues important to small businesses owned by women, as determined by the Task Force. The Task Force focuses on issues such as federal contracts for women-owned small businesses, access to capital for women entrepreneurs, intellectual property rights, and other concerns specific to women-owned small businesses. The Chief Counsel may contract with a public or private entity to conduct a study. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy must submit a report of the study results to the Task Force, Senate Committee on Small Business and Entrepreneurship, and House Committee on Small Business, making it available to the public online. The Task Force report must be made available to the public online. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Task Force. SEC. 4. REPEAL. Final Reports must be submitted by the Interagency Committee on Women's Business Enterprise and the National Women's Business Council within 90 days of this Act's enactment. The reports will contain specific information required by relevant legislation. The Women's Business Ownership Act of 1988 is repealed, and technical amendments are made to the Small Business Act. This includes removing references to the Women's Business Ownership Act in specific sections. The Women's Business Ownership Act of 1988 is repealed, and amendments are made to the Small Business Act, including changes to references and effective dates.
